chapter.title: Templates
chapter.para: The .dtl files are to 70% plain html and just used from frontend modules (Kernel/Modules/*.pm). The .dtl files are located under:
The usable dtl tags and syntax are described below.

sect1.title: Formatting
sect1.para:
TAB: We use two spaces for every new open tag. Examples:
Key Value
aaa bbb
Key1 Value1
Key2 Value2

sect2.title: Comment
sect2.para:
The dtl comment starts with a # at the beginning of a line and will not be shown in the html output.
# this can be a comment in the dtl file

sect2.title: $Data{""}
sect2.para:
If data params are given to the templates, these params can be printed to the template.
The name of the author is $Data{"Name"}.

warning.para: If the value of the param Name includes html tags, these tags are also shown.

sect2.title: $QData{""}
sect2.para:
The same as $Data{""} but the value if the param Name is html quoted (safe).
The name of the author is $QData{"Name"}.
It's also possible to cut the value. If, for example, you just want to show 20 characters of a variable (result will be "SomeName[..]"), use the following:

para.programlisting: The first 20 characters of the author's name: $QData{"Name","20"}.

sect2.title: $LQData{""}
sect2.para: The same as $QData{""} but with link encoding. This means for example that a space will be a + (e. g. for "a href"). $QData{"File","110"}

sect2.title: $Env{""}
$QEnv{""}
sect2.para:
QEnv is an html quoted environment variable (like Env but quoted).
The current user name is: $QEnv{"Userfirstname"}

sect2.title: $Quote{""}
sect2.para:
A tag to quote html strings. Show no html tags, quote this: $Quote{"
some text"}

It's also possible to cut the value. If, for example, you just want to show 20 characters of a variable (result will be "SomeMess[..]"), use the following: Show no html tags, quote this and show just 20 characters: $Quote{"
some text","20"}

sect2.title: $Text{""}
sect2.para:
This tag translates the string (based on the user selected language).
Translate this text: $Text{"Help"}

sect2.title: $Config{""}
sect2.para:
With this tag you can use config variables in the template. For example the Kernel/config.pm:
[Kernel/Config.pm] # FQDN # (Full qualified domain name of your system.) $Self->{FQDN} = 'otrs.example.com'; # AdminEmail # (Email of the system admin.) $Self->{AdminEmail} = 'admin@example.com'; [...]

And the use in the dtl template:
The hostname is '$Config{"FQDN"}' The admin email address is '$Config{"AdminEmail"}'

sect2.title: $Include{""}
sect2.para:
Yet another examlpe:
<html> <head> <tilte>Some Title</tilte> # include css.dtl file $Include{"css"} </head>

sect2.title: Block
sect2.para:
The block tag can be used to define blocks. These blocks can be used several times by the frontend module with different data params.
$Text{"$Data{"Key"}"}:
$QData{"Value","160"}

sect2.title: set
sect2.para:
With this tag you can set a variable in the dtl template.
<dtl set $Data{"Test"} = "Some Text">

sect2.title: if
sect2.para:
It's also possible to use a really "simple" (ne|eq|=~|!~) if condition.
<dtl if ($Text{"Lock"} eq "Lock") { $Data{"Language"} = "en"; }>

Or with a regexp.
<dtl if ($Text{"Lock"} =~ "/text/i") { $Data{"Lala"} = "Matched"; }>

This template function can still be found in several OTRS templates but will be removed in future versions of OTRS. The removal is necessary as a sequence control in the templates is not desired. The function should thus not be used any more.

sect2.title: system-call
sect2.para:
If you want the output of a system call back to a dtl variable.
# execute system call <dtl system-call $Data{"uptime"} = "uptime"> # print The output of 'uptime' is: $Data{"uptime"}

Yet another example:
# execute system call <dtl system-call $Data{"procinfo"} = "procinfo | head -n1 "> # print The output of 'procinfo' is: $Data{"procinfo"}
Usable to set: $Data{""}, $Env{""} and $Config{""}.

para.programlisting:
# set variable <dtl set $Data{"Test1"} = "English">
# print variable Echo: $Data{"Test1"}

# condition <dtl if ($Text{"Lock"} ne "Lock") { $Data{"Test2"} = "Not English!"; }>
# print result Result: $Data{"Test1"}
